newsitem.title: GERMANY: Oil World sees higher Chinese 96/97 soya imports.
newsitem.headline: Oil World sees higher Chinese 96/97 soya imports.

text.p: China's soybean imports in 1996/97 (Oct/Sept) were forecast at 1.5 million tonnes compared with 790,000 tonnes in 95/96, the Oil World newsletter said.
The independent publication said China had quickly started buying U.S. soy oil after it became competitive versus others in the wake of a bearish October 11 U.S. bean crop forecast.
Total soy oil imports by China in 96/97 might rise to a record 1.54 million tonnes versus 1.41 million last year.
Oil World said China needed to import more oils and fats to satisfy rising domestic demand.
Carry-in oil stocks were low and the production of domestic rape oil, groudnut oil, and cotton oil should lag last season.
Its own 96/97 (Aug/July) soybean production may fall to 12.5 million tonnes from 13.3 million in 95/96.

China was also an active buyer of soymeal, which led Oil World to revise a July 30 forecast of 96/97 Chinese soymeal imports by 1.05 million to 2.65 million tonnes, compared with 1.58 million last season.
Oil World also forecast Chinese 96/97 rapeseed oil imports at 365,000 tonnes versus 310,000 tonnes in 95/96.
